description: From Old French bombace (“cotton, cotton wadding”), from Late Latin bombax (“cotton”), a variant of bombyx (“silkworm”), from Ancient Greek βόμβυξ (bómbux, “silkworm”), possibly related to Middle Persian pmbk' (“cotton”), from a Proto-Indo-European root meaning “to twist, wind”.

adjectives.description: bombast (comparative more bombast, superlative most bombast)

entries.meaning: Big without meaning, or high-sounding; bombastic, inflated; magniloquent.
(archaic) Cotton, or any soft, fibrous material, used as stuffing for garments; stuffing, padding.
(figurative) High-sounding words; language above the dignity of the occasion; a pompous or ostentatious manner of writing or speaking.
examples: Synonyms: aureation, (obsolete) bombard phrase, fustian, grandiloquence, purple prose

verbs.description: bombast (third-person singular simple present bombasts, present participle bombasting, simple past and past participle bombasted)

entries.meaning: To swell or fill out; to inflate, to pad.
To use high-sounding words; to speak or write in a pompous or ostentatious manner.
